text: Home › The Asian Pulse › Daily News › After nationwide ceasefire signing, military, political committees formed– 20 Oct 2015 After nationwide ceasefire signing, military, political committees formed– 20 Oct 2015 Tuesday, October 20th, 2015 The so-called Joint Implementing Coordinating Meetings have already resulted in the formation of two joint committees, one for military affairs and the other for political matters. The next JICM will convene on 15 Nov, a week after the election. The NCA calls for the creation of joint monitoring committees at the national, state and region, and local levels to take care of military-related problems. However, at the local level of the monitoring mechanism, religious leaders, other individuals and local residents acceptable to both government and armed ethnic groups will be expected to take part. Specific terms of reference for the operation of the mechanism at its various levels have yet to be finalised. The national or Union-level Joint Monitoring Committee (JMC) is responsible for drafting a military code of conduct and a report of the entire mechanism will be submitted to Joint Implementing Coordinating Meetings, to the public and to the international community every three months. Similarly, the Union Peace Dialogue Joint Committee (UPDJC), which is responsible for drafting the framework for the political dialogue between the ethnic armed groups and the government, will also include third-party representatives from political parties.
